Three problems I can think of:
1. Aren't such partial pathogen vaccines usually paired with adjuvants? Is the therapy able to provide an equivalent boost?
2. Wouldn't this strategy have a high risk of triggering autoimmune issues? I mean, having a patient's cells produce foreign antigens and provoke immune responses...
3. How strongly would the therapeutic genes be expressed? Would the affected cells be able to perform their normal functions effectively?

How do they prevent cells from presenting the antigens on mhc1 and therefore being targeted by nk-cells and cd8+ T-cells? Because for antibody production the antigen needs to be "free" to be taken up by B-cells and dendritic cells for presentation to cd4+ T-cells. Without this there won't be class switch recombination (needed for memory b-cells) and somatic hypermutation (needed for more effective antibodies).

The point of this type of vaccine is that we modify some of our bodies cells to produce the antigens to train our immune system.
Instead of culturing the antigens in labs and introducing them into our body. You need very little DNA to achieve the result, this is why it could be a lot cheaper at large scale.
How long the modified cells stay around doesn't matter so much. The protection comes from the trained immune system.
And as far as I know the cells DNS isn't actually 'modified' per se. Additional RNA is introduced into the cell.

An addendum would be that this procedure only works for immunocompetent people. There are also similar methods to be employed in immunodeficient or -comprised people (such as AIDS patients, medically immunosupressed people etc.). For those you try to find a broadly neutralizing antibody (basically monoclonal antibody populations that mostly block or inhibit virus adhesion etc.) and then introduce its genetic sequence into the body (most often tissues such as the skeletal muscle for their mass and metabolic activity), thereby creating immunity without a need for the actual immune system that may or may not be dysfunctional.

Given the relatively low mortality rate for young people this seems too risky to me to fast track. There is a serious risk here of us allowing panic to get the better of us and allowing risky science to let something terrible slip through the cracks. Our best tools to combat COVID right now are epidemiological at this point. Social distancing, contact tracing, disallowing large gatherings etc. Research like this of course should be perused but we have to be careful not to fast track things that we would normally use an abundance of caution with.
